measured_by: Ratings of each party’s welfare change on a –5 (worse) to +5 (better) scale after reading transaction vignettes; proportion of non-beneficiary judgments derived from these ratings
justification: Participants “rated the welfare of the buyer and seller… on a scale anchored at -5 (‘Worse than before’), 0 (‘Same as before’), and 5 (‘Better than before’).… Nearly all participants… indicated that at least one party was made worse-off… this was our measure of win-win denial and zero-sum thinking.”

measured_by: Single-item 0 (‘Not knowledgeable’) to 10 (‘Very knowledgeable’) self-rating scale
justification: Methods: “Participants were also asked about … economics knowledge (‘Please rate your knowledge of economics’ on a scale from 0 to 10).”

measured_by: Continuous 0 (liberal) to 10 (conservative) scale for economic issues
justification: Methods: participants reported “values on economic issues, each on continuous 0 (Democrat/liberal) to 10 (Republican/conservative) scales.”

measured_by: Continuous 0 (liberal) to 10 (conservative) scale for social issues
justification: Methods state that participants indicated “values on social issues” using the same 0–10 liberal-to-conservative scale.
Participants were asked about “party affiliation… on continuous 0 (Democrat/liberal) to 10 (Republican/conservative) scales,” providing a quantitative measure of party identification.
